title: Diophantine equation
problem:
Consider quadratic Diophantine equations of the form:
x2 – Dy2 = 1
For example, when D=13, the minimal solution in x is 6492 – 13×1802 = 1.
It can be assumed that there are no solutions in positive integers when D is square.
By finding minimal solutions in x for D = {2, 3, 5, 6, 7}, we obtain the following:
32 – 2×22 = 1
22 – 3×12 = 192 – 5×42 = 1
52 – 6×22 = 1
82 – 7×32 = 1
Hence, by considering minimal solutions in x for D ≤ 7, the largest x is obtained when D=5.
Find the value of D ≤ 1000 in minimal solutions of x for which the largest value of x is obtained.
story:
Once upon a time, in a quaint little town surrounded by rolling hills, there lived a young girl named Eliza. Eliza was known for her curious mind and her love for solving puzzles. She solved every riddle and brainteaser that came her way, but she yearned for a challenge that would truly test her abilities.

One sunny morning, as Eliza was walking in the town square, she stumbled upon a peculiar old book lying on a wooden bench. The book seemed untouched by time, its pages yellowed and brittle. Intrigued, Eliza opened it, and her eyes fell upon a chapter titled "The Mysterious Quadratic Diophantine Equations."

The first few paragraphs described a mathematical problem that piqued Eliza's interest. She immersed herself in the story of the ancient mathematicians who were fascinated by the patterns hidden within the quadratic Diophantine equations. Gradually, her fascination evolved into an obsession, and every day after school, Eliza would rush back home just to pour over the books in the town library.

Days turned into weeks, and weeks turned into months. Eliza's determination was unwavering. She diligently worked her way through countless equations and mathematical riddles, collecting scraps of paper adorned with her complex calculations. The more she discovered, the further she delved into the world of these mysterious equations.

As Eliza mastered the art of solving quadratic Diophantine equations, her excitement reached new heights. She decided to challenge herself and search for the values of "D" that would yield the largest "x" in minimal solutions. With every equation she solved, she grew closer to her ultimate goal.

Months turned into years, and Eliza's hard work eventually led her to find the largest "x" for values of "D" up to 1000. She reveled in the knowledge she had gained from her tireless pursuit, but she hungered to share her findings with others. Eliza couldn't bear the thought of keeping her newfound treasure to herself.

One cool autumn evening, Eliza gathered the townsfolk in the town square. With her heart racing, she stood on a makeshift platform, clutching her findings in a bundle of papers. The townspeople eagerly leaned in, eager to learn the secrets she was about to share.

"Friends," Eliza began with a gleam in her eyes, "I have spent years decoding the mysteries of the quadratic Diophantine equations. Today, I present to you the largest value of 'x' for which the minimal solutions are derived for 'D' values up to 1000."

She unfolded a large poster, showcasing a meticulously written table, with 'D' and the corresponding 'x' values carefully engraved. The townspeople gasped, realizing the magnitude of Eliza's discovery. They marveled at her dedication and the beauty of the mathematical world she had uncovered.

Amidst the whispers and applause, Eliza finished her presentation with a thought-provoking question: "Now, dear townsfolk, I pose this mathematical puzzle to all of you: Can you find the value of 'D' up to 1000 for which the largest 'x' is obtained in the minimal solutions? In this elaborate web of numbers and equations, lies the answer to our collective challenge."

The townspeople were filled with a sense of excitement and wonder. They had seen the passion burning within Eliza, and they knew that unraveling this mathematical enigma would be a voyage of discovery.

And so, my dear reader, I pose the same question to you: Can you find the value of 'D' up to 1000 in minimal solutions of 'x' for which the largest 'x' is obtained? Are you ready to embark on this mathematical journey and unravel the secrets hidden within the realm of quadratic Diophantine equations?

title: Magic 5-gon ring
problem:
Consider the following "magic" 3-gon ring, filled with the numbers 1 to 6, and each line adding to nine.


Working clockwise, and starting from the group of three with the numerically lowest external node (4,3,2 in this example), each solution can be described uniquely. For example, the above solution can be described by the set: 4,3,2; 6,2,1; 5,1,3.
It is possible to complete the ring with four different totals: 9, 10, 11, and 12. There are eight solutions in total.

TotalSolution Set
94,2,3; 5,3,1; 6,1,2
94,3,2; 6,2,1; 5,1,3
102,3,5; 4,5,1; 6,1,3
102,5,3; 6,3,1; 4,1,5
111,4,6; 3,6,2; 5,2,4
111,6,4; 5,4,2; 3,2,6
121,5,6; 2,6,4; 3,4,5
121,6,5; 3,5,4; 2,4,6

By concatenating each group it is possible to form 9-digit strings; the maximum string for a 3-gon ring is 432621513.
Using the numbers 1 to 10, and depending on arrangements, it is possible to form 16- and 17-digit strings. What is the maximum 16-digit string for a "magic" 5-gon ring?

title: Singular integer right triangles
problem:
It turns out that 12 cm is the smallest length of wire that can be bent to form an integer sided right angle triangle in exactly one way, but there are many more examples.
12 cm: (3,4,5)24 cm: (6,8,10)30 cm: (5,12,13)36 cm: (9,12,15)40 cm: (8,15,17)48 cm: (12,16,20)
In contrast, some lengths of wire, like 20 cm, cannot be bent to form an integer sided right angle triangle, and other lengths allow more than one solution to be found; for example, using 120 cm it is possible to form exactly three different integer sided right angle triangles.
120 cm: (30,40,50), (20,48,52), (24,45,51)
Given that L is the length of the wire, for how many values of L ≤ 1,500,000 can exactly one integer sided right angle triangle be formed?
story:
Once upon a time in the small village of Pythagore, there lived a young blacksmith named Thomas. Thomas was known for his precision and attention to detail, making him the most sought-after blacksmith in the land. One day, a farmer named Henry approached Thomas with a unique request.

"Thomas, I need your help," Henry said with a worried expression on his face. "I recently inherited a plot of land, and I've been having strange dreams about buried treasure. I believe there might be something valuable hidden beneath the soil, but I'm not sure where to start digging."

Intrigued by the mystery, Thomas agreed to assist Henry in his quest for treasure. The two men gathered their tools and set off towards the farm. Upon arrival, they began examining the land in search of any clues that could lead them to the hidden riches.

As they walked across the uneven terrain, Thomas stumbled upon a peculiar piece of wire sticking out of the ground. Sensing that it might hold some significance, he carefully pulled it out and inspected it closely. The wire was exactly 12 centimeters long, and something about its shape intrigued Thomas.

He remembered a mathematical problem he had once come across during his studies: the smallest length of wire that could be bent to form an integer-sided right-angled triangle in only one way. The wire in his hand fit the description perfectly. The problem pervaded his thoughts, as if it held the key to unlocking the mystery beneath Henry's farm.

Unable to let go of the connection between the wire and the treasure, Thomas shared his discovery with Henry. The farmer's face lit up with excitement, realizing that this mathematical problem could be the key to uncovering the location of the buried riches.

"If we can find more wires with the same properties," Henry exclaimed, "we might be able to triangulate the exact spot where the treasure lies."

With renewed determination, Thomas and Henry began searching the land, meticulously measuring each piece of wire they found. They discovered wires measuring 24 cm, 30 cm, 36 cm, and even 40 cm. Each wire could only fit into a right-angled triangle in one unique way.

As they continued their search, they stumbled upon a wire measuring 120 cm. It astonished them to find that this length could form three distinct right-angled triangles.

"There must be something significant about these measurements," Thomas mused, "and I believe they hold the key to finding the treasure you seek."

Days turned into weeks, and the duo scoured every inch of the farm, discovering an array of wire lengths that satisfied the mathematical problem. The list grew longer and longer, yet they still couldn't pinpoint the precise location of the treasure.

Finally, standing exhausted in the center of the land, Thomas looked at Henry with a glimmer of hope in his eyes. "Henry, my friend, I think I've solved it. We have found wires of numerous lengths that can form exactly one integer-sided right-angled triangle. But the question remains—how many values of L below 1,500,000 can satisfy this condition?"

Thomas stared at Henry, who was equally captivated by the enigma. The two friends knew that somewhere within the answer lay the secret to unlocking the buried treasure.

And so, the question hung in the air, leaving Thomas and Henry with a sense of anticipation and a burning desire to unravel the mathematical mystery that would ultimately lead them to their long-awaited fortune.

Dear reader, can you solve the mathematical problem that Thomas and Henry encountered on their adventure? How many values of L below 1,500,000 can form exactly one integer-sided right-angled triangle?

title: Prime summations
problem:
It is possible to write ten as the sum of primes in exactly five different ways:
7 + 3
5 + 5
5 + 3 + 2
3 + 3 + 2 + 2
2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 2
What is the first value which can be written as the sum of primes in over five thousand different ways?
story:
Once upon a time in the magical land of Arithmetica, there lived a young and talented wizard named Merlin. Merlin had always possessed a knack for numbers and patterns, often spending his days engrossed in magical equations that had been lost to time. His favorites were the prime numbers, those special digits that could only be divided evenly by one and themselves.

One sunny morning, while Merlin was strolling through the enchanted forest, he encountered a talking squirrel named Sherman. The little rodent was perched on a branch, munching on acorns and mumbling to himself.

Curiosity piqued, Merlin approached Sherman and politely asked, "Excuse me, Sherman, but why the solemn expression?"

Sherman paused mid-chew and turned his beady eyes towards Merlin. "Ah, Merlin! Just the wizard I was hoping to see! I've been pondering a mathematical problem that has me rather perplexed."

The wizard, always eager for a challenge, raised an intrigued eyebrow. "Pray tell, Sherman, what seems to be the issue?"

Sherman swallowed his mouthful of acorn and began, "Merlin, you see, it is possible to write ten, a mere humble number, as the sum of primes in exactly five different ways. But my furry friend, I wonder, what is the first value which can be written as the sum of primes in over five thousand different ways?"

Merlin's eyes widened, his mind instantly whirling in an intricate dance of numbers and possibilities. Excitement alighted upon his face as he realized the gravity of Sherman's question.

"If such a number exists," Merlin exclaimed, "it would be an astonishing feat indeed! Let us embark on a quest, my dear friend, to unlock the mystery of this enigmatic entity!"

With Sherman perched on his shoulder, the pair ventured through the magical land of Arithmetica, seeking guidance from ancient mathematicians, consulting dusty tomes, and tinkering with arcane calculations. As their journey unfolded, they discovered fascinating numerical patterns—the Goldbach Conjecture, the Sieve of Eratosthenes, and even the hidden beauty within the Fibonacci sequence.

Days turned into weeks as Merlin and Sherman traversed mountains, crossed vast rivers, and braved treacherous forests, all in the pursuit of their ultimate goal. But every step brought them closer to the elusive solution they so fervently sought.

Their quest eventually led them to the grand library of Arithmetica, renowned for its magical manuscripts and insurmountable wealth of knowledge. Reading diligently through ancient scrolls illuminated by shimmering candlelight, their eyes sparkled with the excitement of discovery.

As the night waned into dawn, Merlin and Sherman continued to absorb the wisdom contained within the library's hallowed halls. The answer they sought remained tantalizingly out of reach, just beyond the grasp of their combined intellect.

And so, dear reader, I leave you with the same question posed by Sherman to the wise and curious Merlin: What is the first value which can be written as the sum of primes in over five thousand different ways? Can you unlock the numerical mysteries of Arithmetica and satiate the hunger of curiosity that gnaws at our heroes' souls?

In this great realm of infinite possibilities, we implore you—hidden within the realms of arithmetic, primes, and patterned enigmas, what numerical wonder awaits discovery?

title: Right triangles with integer coordinates
problem:
The points P (x1, y1) and Q (x2, y2) are plotted at integer co-ordinates and are joined to the origin, O(0,0), to form ΔOPQ.


There are exactly fourteen triangles containing a right angle that can be formed when each co-ordinate lies between 0 and 2 inclusive; that is,0 ≤ x1, y1, x2, y2 ≤ 2.


Given that 0 ≤ x1, y1, x2, y2 ≤ 50, how many right triangles can be formed?
story:
Once upon a time, in the charming village of Numeralia, there lived a curious young girl named Ariadne. While her friends spent their days playing in the meadows, Ariadne found wonder in the world of numbers. Her fascination with mathematics was unstoppable, and she often pondered about the secrets hidden within those symbols and equations.

Ariadne's heart raced with excitement as Professor Calculus unveiled the problem. "The points P(x1, y1) and Q(x2, y2) are plotted at integer coordinates and are joined to the origin, O(0,0), to form ΔOPQ. There are exactly fourteen triangles containing a right angle that can be formed when each coordinate lies between 0 and 2 inclusive; that is, 0 ≤ x1, y1, x2, y2 ≤ 2. But let me ask you this: Given that 0 ≤ x1, y1, x2, y2 ≤ 50, how many right triangles can be formed?"

Ariadne's eyes widened with eagerness as she immediately began pondering the problem. It was like being presented with a captivating puzzle, and every cell in her being pushed her to unravel its mysteries.

That evening, Ariadne sat by the village fountain, lost in concentration. Drawing circles and connecting dots, she crafted countless triangles in search of those elusive right angles. Her mind danced with numbers, patterns, and shapes as the moonlight mingled with her inspiration.

The professor nodded, his smile growing. "Indeed, Ariadne," he replied. "Mathematics has a magical quality; it allows us to both understand the universe and explore the depths of our own minds. What is your answer?"

Ariadne took a deep breath and spoke with confidence. "Given that 0 ≤ x1, y1, x2, y2 ≤ 50, there are a total of __ right triangles that can be formed."

The professor's eyes gleamed with pride as he grasped the significance of Ariadne's journey. "Well done, Ariadne," he said. "You've discovered something far greater than the solution to a math problem. You've discovered the joys of intellectual pursuit. And now, it's time to share this gift with the world."

And so, Ariadne stood upon a stage, her voice ringing with enthusiasm, as she shared the tale of her mathematical quest. Her words echoed through the village, leaving the audience captivated by the power of numbers and the beauty hidden within triangles.

As her story drew to a close, Ariadne gazed into the crowd, her eyes full of anticipation. She raised her voice one final time, invoking a question that would inspire the villagers to embark on their own journeys of discovery.

"Now, my friends," she said, a twinkle in her eye, "I have shared with you the wonders of this mystical problem. I have discovered the answer, but will you embark on your own adventure to find it? Given that 0 ≤ x1, y1, x2, y2 ≤ 50, I ask you: How many right triangles can be formed?"

And with that, the village erupted in applause, each villager ready to seek their answers, ready to explore the hidden depths of the mathematical universe, just as Ariadne had shown them.

As the villagers dispersed, Ariadne found herself surrounded by eager students, ready to embark on their own journeys of curiosity and mathematical exploration. And so, dear reader, I ask you: How many right triangles can be formed? Will you follow in Ariadne's footsteps and unravel the secrets hidden within the coordinates or let the mystery remain a puzzle forever?

title: Pandigital Fibonacci ends
problem:
The Fibonacci sequence is defined by the recurrence relation:
Fn = Fn−1 + Fn−2, where F1 = 1 and F2 = 1.
It turns out that F541, which contains 113 digits, is the first Fibonacci number for which the last nine digits are 1-9 pandigital (contain all the digits 1 to 9, but not necessarily in order). And F2749, which contains 575 digits, is the first Fibonacci number for which the first nine digits are 1-9 pandigital.
Given that Fk is the first Fibonacci number for which the first nine digits AND the last nine digits are 1-9 pandigital, find k.
story:

title: Square remainders
problem:
Let r be the remainder when (a−1)n + (a+1)n is divided by a2.
For example, if a = 7 and n = 3, then r = 42: 63 + 83 = 728 ≡ 42 mod 49. And as n varies, so too will r, but for a = 7 it turns out that rmax = 42.
For 3 ≤ a ≤ 1000, find ∑ rmax.
story:
Once upon a time in a quaint little village called Numerica, there lived a young girl named Ada. Ada was not your ordinary girl; she had an insatiable curiosity for numbers and the mysteries they held. Every day, she would spend hours poring over math books that were far beyond her grade level, exploring the hidden realms of prime numbers and complex equations.

One bright sunny morning, as Ada sat under her favorite oak tree, she stumbled upon a peculiar mathematical problem. It captivated her instantly. Let r be the remainder when (a−1)n + (a+1)n is divided by a^2. Ada was fascinated by the idea that this remainder, r, varied as both a and n changed. The idea of unraveling the secrets of r intrigued her to no end.

As the days turned into weeks, Ada's relentless pursuit of r consumed her every thought. The people in the village, amazed by her passion for mathematics, began to refer to her as the "Mathematical Muse." Even the wise old villagers would come to her seeking guidance on their own mathematical conundrums.

News of Ada's adventures in Numerica spread far and wide, even reaching the ears of a renowned mathematician named Professor Euler. Intrigued by tales of this young prodigy, he traveled to Numerica to meet Ada and understand the nature of her mathematical problem.

With a twinkle in his wise eyes, Professor Euler engaged Ada in a conversation that lasted until the moon rose high in the sky. Together, they deduced that this peculiar problem had several implications. Not only did it have applications in number theory, but it also held the key to unlocking patterns and unraveling the secrets of a and n.

Ada, thrilled by the collaboration, wondered if there was a way to solve this problem for a broader range of values. She yearned to know if there were any patterns or relationships between a, n, and r. Professor Euler proposed a challenge for Ada—to find the sum of rmax for 3 ≤ a ≤ 1000. It was an arduous task, but Ada was determined to accept the challenge and solve this mathematical mystery.

Days turned into months, and Ada's enthusiasm never waned. She worked diligently, tirelessly scribbling numbers and equations into her notebook. Under the oak tree where she first discovered the problem, Ada persevered, unlocking the secrets of r one by one.

The villagers watched in awe as Ada's journey progressed. They marveled at her unwavering resolve, her love for numbers, and her tireless pursuit of knowledge. No one doubted that she would eventually find the answer to Professor Euler's challenge.

And so, dear reader, the question now falls to you. Can you find the sum of rmax for 3 ≤ a ≤ 1000? Can you uncover the hidden patterns that lie within this mathematical problem? Take a moment to ponder, let your mind wander, and perhaps, just perhaps, you will find the elusive solution that has eluded not only Ada but also countless mathematicians before her.

title: Ordered radicals

If we calculate rad(n) for 1 ≤ n ≤ 10, then sort them on rad(n), and sorting on n if the radical values are equal, we get:

If rad(n) is sorted for 1 ≤ n ≤ 100000, find E(10000).

title: Palindromic sums
problem:
The palindromic number 595 is interesting because it can be written as the sum of consecutive squares: 62 + 72 + 82 + 92 + 102 + 112 + 122.
There are exactly eleven palindromes below one-thousand that can be written as consecutive square sums, and the sum of these palindromes is 4164. Note that 1 = 02 + 12 has not been included as this problem is concerned with the squares of positive integers.
Find the sum of all the numbers less than 108 that are both palindromic and can be written as the sum of consecutive squares.
story:
Once upon a time in the bustling town of Numeria, young Benjamin found an old, dusty book in the attic of his grandfather's house. The book seemed ordinary at first, with its worn-out pages and faded cover. However, little did Benjamin know that this book held a secret beyond his wildest imagination.

As Benjamin flipped through the pages, his eyes stumbled upon a story titled "The Enchanted Equation." His curiosity piqued, he began to read.

The story spoke of an ancient kingdom where magic and mathematics coexisted in harmony. The kingdom had long been protected by a magical number - a palindromic number. It fascinated Benjamin to think that a number could possess such power. This particular number was 595, the sum of consecutive squares: 62 + 72 + 82 + 92 + 102 + 112 + 122.

In the kingdom's archives, Benjamin discovered an astonishing entry. It revealed that there were precisely eleven palindromes below one-thousand that could be written as consecutive square sums. These eleven numbers held a hidden connection to the ancient enchantment - their sum equaled 4164.

Mesmerized, Benjamin spent days studying the book, delving deeper into the wonders of mathematics, and pondering the meaning hidden within. He began devising his own equations and testing his newfound knowledge.

"Might there be a way to unlock the secrets of the enchanted equation?" Benjamin wondered aloud. As he continued his exploration, he found himself drawn further into the world of palindromes and sums of consecutive squares.

In his quest, Benjamin realized that he yearned to find all the palindromic numbers that could be written as the sum of consecutive squares below a specific threshold. With great ambition, he posed himself a challenge - to discover the sum of all the numbers less than 108 that fulfilled these conditions.

Armed with enthusiasm and determination, Benjamin studied the patterns that emerged within the mathematics. He worked tirelessly, hours slipping away as he feverishly scribbled formulas and equations on stacks of paper.

As Benjamin ventured further into his mathematical journey, he began to see connections between numbers he had never considered before. He marveled at the hidden symmetries and the intricate dances between the squares, their sums, and the palindromes they formed.

The boy's excitement grew with each revelation, but the answer still eluded him. How could he uncover the sum of all the palindromic numbers that were less than 108 and could be written as the sum of consecutive squares?

Now, dear reader, I pose this question to you: Can you unravel the mysteries of the enchanted equation? Can you calculate the sum that Benjamin so ardently sought?

title: Consecutive positive divisors
problem: Find the number of integers 1 < n < 107, for which n and n + 1 have the same number of positive divisors. For example, 14 has the positive divisors 1, 2, 7, 14 while 15 has 1, 3, 5, 15.
story:
Once upon a time, in the enchanted kingdom of Numeria, there was a young prince named Ethan. Prince Ethan possessed a sharp mind, always curious about the world around him. His father, King Alistair, recognized Ethan's intelligence and nurtured it by providing him with the most knowledgeable tutors.

One sunny afternoon, as Prince Ethan was engrossed in his studies at the royal library, a peculiar book caught his attention. Its worn-out pages were filled with intricate mathematical problems and riddles. The prince, unable to resist the challenge, eagerly began to solve the first problem he stumbled upon.

The problem posed an intriguing question: "Find the number of integers, 1 < n < 107, for which n and n + 1 have the same number of positive divisors." Captivated by the puzzle, Prince Ethan immersed himself in the world of divisors and prime numbers.

Days turned into weeks as Ethan devoted himself to solving the problem, setting aside his princely duties. He consulted with the kingdom's wisest mathematicians and even reached out to other kingdoms to gather additional insight. The more he delved into the depths of divisors, the more enthralled he became.

Meanwhile, the people of Numeria grew concerned about their absent prince. The kingdom, afflicted by a mysterious ailment, needed their leader's guidance more than ever. However, Prince Ethan remained unfazed, determined to unravel the mathematical mystery before him.

One stormy night, while poring over the problem again, an epiphany struck Ethan like a lightning bolt. He discovered a connection between the number of positive divisors and the prime factorization of a number. His eyes widened with excitement, realizing that he was on the verge of unlocking the answer.

Suddenly, a knock on the door interrupted his jubilation. It was his loyal friend and advisor, Sir William. Concern and anxiety were etched on Sir William's face. "My Prince, the people of Numeria are in desperate need of your guidance. They eagerly await your return."

Prince Ethan, torn between his love for the people and his desire to solve the mathematical problem, faced a challenging decision. Duty and loyalty warred within him, intensifying his inner struggle.

As the clouds outside raged, mirroring Ethan's turbulent emotions, he flipped a coin, letting fate decide. However, just before it landed, his instincts took over, and he caught the coin mid-air. In that split second, he knew he could not ignore his responsibility as a prince any longer.

With a heavy heart, Prince Ethan closed the book of mathematical puzzles and returned to his kingdom. Though he had not solved the problem, he carried with him the knowledge gained from this mathematical journey.

As the short story comes to an end, the reader is left with a question: How many integers within the range of 1 < n < 107 have the same number of positive divisors as their consecutive number, n + 1?

title: Semiprimes
problem:
A composite is a number containing at least two prime factors. For example, 15 = 3 × 5; 9 = 3 × 3; 12 = 2 × 2 × 3.
There are ten composites below thirty containing precisely two, not necessarily distinct, prime factors:
4, 6, 9, 10, 14, 15, 21, 22, 25, 26.
How many composite integers, n < 108, have precisely two, not necessarily distinct, prime factors?
story:
Once upon a time in the vibrant kingdom of Arithmos, there lived a young prince named Theo. As the son of King Julius and Queen Isabella, Theo was destined to inherit the throne when he came of age. However, he was far more interested in solving puzzles and exploring the wonders of the kingdom than ruling over it.

One sunny morning, as Theo strolled through the lush gardens of the palace, he stumbled upon an old book tucked away beneath a rosebush. The pages were filled with intriguing mathematical problems, sparking Theo's curiosity. Eager to challenge his logical mind, he opened the book and began to read.

Among the problems he encountered, one in particular caught Theo's attention. It spoke of composites, numbers composed of at least two prime factors. Fascinated by their properties, he delved deeper into the matter. The book revealed a list of ten composites below thirty that possessed precisely two prime factors: 4, 6, 9, 10, 14, 15, 21, 22, 25, and 26.

This mathematical marvel intrigued Theo. He envisioned himself as a hero on a quest to discover the number of composite integers below a certain threshold that had precisely two prime factors. The challenge seemed daunting, but the young prince was determined to find the solution.

Undeterred by his princely duties, Theo retreated to his study and spent countless hours immersed in the world of numbers. The book became his constant companion, its pages dog-eared and worn from his intense study sessions.

Days turned into weeks, and weeks into months, as Theo diligently explored the relationships between prime numbers and composites. The more he delved into the subject, the clearer his understanding became. The prince found beauty in the patterns and symmetries that governed the numerical realm.

As time passed, Theo's fascination grew into an obsession; he yearned to uncover the answer to the question that had consumed him. Hours of calculations and countless scribbles littered his desk, but a solution eluded him.

One gloomy evening, as raindrops tapped rhythmically against the windowpane, Theo's brow furrowed in frustration. He had reached an impasse, unable to see the path that would lead him to the answer he sought. Doubt began to creep into his mind as he wondered if his pursuit had been in vain.

That very night, as Theo lay in bed, tossing and turning, he dreamt of the kingdom of Arithmos. In this fantastical world, numbers danced and twirled, forming a symphony of patterns and melodies. Amidst the numerical symphony, a question emerged, resounding through his dreams. How many composite integers, n < 108, have precisely two, not necessarily distinct, prime factors?

Theo awoke with a newfound determination, his tired eyes sparking with a flame of inspiration. The answer he desired was within reach; he could feel it in his bones. With renewed vigor, he dove back into his studies, his focus unyielding.

Weeks turned into months, and months turned into years. Theo was consumed by his quest, his determination unwavering. Time seemed to lose all meaning as he became one with the numbers, working tirelessly to uncover the elusive solution.

As the years rolled by, Theo's study bore witness to his transformation. The walls were adorned with charts and graphs, while stacks of books lined every available surface. The young prince had become a man deeply invested in the pursuit of knowledge.

And so, the question remains. How many composite integers, n < 108, have precisely two, not necessarily distinct, prime factors?

Dear reader, can you find the answer that eluded Prince Theo? In this realm of numbers, where patterns echo and logic intertwines, the solution awaits.

title: Squarefree Binomial Coefficients
problem:
The binomial coefficients (nk) can be arranged in triangular form, Pascal's triangle, like this:

111121133114641151010511615201561172135352171
.........

It can be seen that the first eight rows of Pascal's triangle contain twelve distinct numbers: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 10, 15, 20, 21 and 35.
A positive integer n is called squarefree if no square of a prime divides n.
Of the twelve distinct numbers in the first eight rows of Pascal's triangle, all except 4 and 20 are squarefree.
The sum of the distinct squarefree numbers in the first eight rows is 105.
Find the sum of the distinct squarefree numbers in the first 51 rows of Pascal's triangle.
story:
Once upon a time, in the Kingdom of Numeria, there lived a young princess named Penelope. Penelope was a curious and intelligent girl, always eager to explore the wonders of her kingdom. She loved to find patterns and solve puzzles, for her mind was sharp as a needle.

One sunny afternoon, as Penelope played in the royal garden, her eyes were drawn to a beautiful butterfly fluttering about. It had intricate patterns on its wings, resembling a triangular shape. Fascinated, Penelope followed the butterfly until it led her to the royal library. Determined to unravel the mystery behind the butterfly's pattern, she ventured inside.

The library was a vast space filled with countless books, and as Penelope gazed upon the shelves, her eyes fell upon an old, dusty tome. Drawn to it, she carefully removed it from the shelf. The book was titled "The Enigma of Pascal's Triangle." Intrigued, the princess opened it, and as she perused its pages, her eyes widened with excitement.

She discovered that Pascal's Triangle, a renowned mathematical wonder, held within its rows an array of numbers that seemed to hold secrets. Penelope's mathematical mind began to unravel the patterns and meaning behind these numbers. She learned that the triangle could be formed by adding two adjacent numbers from the previous row. It was a mathematical wonder that enchanted her, and she couldn't wait to delve further into its mysteries.

Poring over the pages, Penelope discovered a tantalizing problem. The author stated that the first eight rows of Pascal's Triangle contained twelve distinct numbers, all of which were squarefree except for 4 and 20. Intrigued, Penelope wondered what made these numbers different. With a tip of her quill, she calculated the sum of these squarefree numbers, finding it to be 105.

The discovery left Penelope with an insatiable hunger for knowledge. She yearned to unlock the secrets of the remaining rows of Pascal's Triangle. Determined, she formulated a plan. She would delve deep into the recesses of the ancient library, searching for more clues. Perhaps hidden within the pages of forgotten books lay the key to unraveling the mystery of the entire triangle.

As weeks turned into months, Penelope tirelessly researched, her days spent pouring over countless dusty tomes. She discovered fascinating connections between the rows of Pascal's Triangle and other mathematical concepts such as number theory and combinatorics. Every discovery brought her closer to the truth, deepening her love for mathematics.

Finally, after months of tireless dedication, Penelope had a breakthrough. She managed to calculate the sum of the distinct squarefree numbers in the first 51 rows of Pascal's Triangle. But just as she stood on the precipice of solving the entire mathematical puzzle, a new question emerged.

The princess realized that she alone could not unearth the answer. The riddle of the distinct squarefree numbers in Pascal's Triangle begged to be solved by a collective effort, a synergy of minds. With a determined gleam in her eye, Penelope put down her quill and asked herself: "Dear reader, will you take up the challenge? Can you find the sum of the distinct squarefree numbers in the first 51 rows of Pascal's Triangle?"

And so, the quest to decipher the hidden patterns and unveil the sum of these numbers passed from Penelope to the reader, a challenge waiting to be met. The tale of Pascal's Triangle and its enigmatic numbers would forever be etched in the annals of Numeria, waiting for a curious mind to set foot on the path of discovery.

title: Prime Frog
problem:
Susan has a prime frog.
Her frog is jumping around over 500 squares numbered 1 to 500.
He can only jump one square to the left or to the right, with equal probability, and he cannot jump outside the range [1;500].(if it lands at either end, it automatically jumps to the only available square on the next move.)


When he is on a square with a prime number on it, he croaks 'P' (PRIME) with probability 2/3 or 'N' (NOT PRIME) with probability 1/3 just before jumping to the next square.
When he is on a square with a number on it that is not a prime he croaks 'P' with probability 1/3 or 'N' with probability 2/3 just before jumping to the next square.


Given that the frog's starting position is random with the same probability for every square, and given that she listens to his first 15 croaks, what is the probability that she hears the sequence PPPPNNPPPNPPNPN?

Give your answer as a fraction p/q in reduced form.
story:
Once upon a time, in a quaint little town called Primeton, lived a young girl named Susan. Susan was a curious and intelligent child, always seeking adventure and knowledge in every corner of her world. One sunny morning, as she played near the town pond, she made an extraordinary discovery. Resting on a lily pad was a peculiar, green frog with a crown-shaped spot on its head. To Susan's surprise, the frog could speak and had a profound understanding of mathematics.

"I am no ordinary frog, Susan," the frog croaked with a mischievous smile. "I possess the power of primes, and I can solve mathematical puzzles like no other creature in Primeton."

Intrigued by this extraordinary claim, Susan decided to put the frog's abilities to the test. She grabbed a pencil and paper and presented the frog with a mathematical problem she had recently come across.

"Susan, dear, what is your mathematical conundrum?" the frog curiously inquired.

She read aloud to the frog the problem about the prime frog jumping across 500 numbered squares. The frog listened attentively as Susan recounted the peculiarities of its croaking patterns, depending on whether the square it was on contained a prime number or not.

As Susan spoke, the frog's bright eyes sparkled with excitement, revealing that this problem was truly remarkable. It hopped around, collecting pebbles with numbers on them, arranging them to mimic the sequence described in the problem.

"Now, Susan," the frog said, placing the pebbles in a pattern precisely reflecting the sequence PPPPNNPPPNPPNPN. "This sequence is no ordinary melody. Its composition reflects a balance of primes and non-primes, of order and chaos. The question is, can you predict the probabilities of hearing it?"

Susan gazed at the frog, eager for the answer. She had been captivated by its wisdom, kneeling closer as if about to receive an enchanting tale.

"I have," the frog continued, "calculated the probabilities like a sorcerer conducting a symphony of numbers. Yet, only you possess the power to uncover the hidden truth. So, dear Susan, tell me, what is the probability you will hear this sequence in the first fifteen croaks?"

Susan's mind whirled with the possibilities, recognizing the importance of calculating this probability correctly. She knew that by understanding the probability, she could uncover deeper truths about the world of primes and harness the power of the frog's wisdom.

But how would she proceed? What steps would she take to unlock the answer to such a perplexing problem? The challenge lay before her, beckoning her to delve deep into the realm of numbers.

As Susan pondered her next move, she glanced back at the frog, who watched her with anticipation. The town of Primeton buzzed with excitement, oblivious to the fantastic adventure brewing between a young girl and her prime frog companion.

And so, with determination in her eyes and a spark of curiosity in her heart, Susan embarks on a mathematical journey. Will she uncover the great secret behind the frog's croaking patterns? Can she solve the riddle that weaves numbers and probability into an extraordinary tale? The answer lies within each and every one of us. Can you crack the code and calculate the probability that Susan hears the sequence PPPPNNPPPNPPNPN?

The adventure awaits, and the solution lies within your grasp.

title: Maximix Arrangements
problem:
A train is used to transport four carriages in the order: ABCD. However, sometimes when the train arrives to collect the carriages they are not in the correct order. 
To rearrange the carriages they are all shunted on to a large rotating turntable. After the carriages are uncoupled at a specific point the train moves off the turntable pulling the carriages still attached with it. The remaining carriages are rotated 180 degrees. All of the carriages are then rejoined and this process is repeated as often as necessary in order to obtain the least number of uses of the turntable.
Some arrangements, such as ADCB, can be solved easily: the carriages are separated between A and D, and after DCB are rotated the correct order has been achieved.
However, Simple Simon, the train driver, is not known for his efficiency, so he always solves the problem by initially getting carriage A in the correct place, then carriage B, and so on.
Using four carriages, the worst possible arrangements for Simon, which we shall call maximix arrangements, are DACB and DBAC; each requiring him five rotations (although, using the most efficient approach, they could be solved using just three rotations). The process he uses for DACB is shown below.

It can be verified that there are 24 maximix arrangements for six carriages, of which the tenth lexicographic maximix arrangement is DFAECB.
Find the 2011th lexicographic maximix arrangement for eleven carriages.
story:
Once upon a time in a charming little village, nestled in the heart of the countryside, lived a passionate train driver named Simple Simon. Simon was known for his dedication and love for his job. He commanded a small locomotive that transported carriages from one side of the village to the other.

Simon took great pride in his ability to efficiently organize the train's carriages. Day in and day out, he followed a particular process to ensure that the carriages were in the correct order when they left the station. He diligently arranged the carriages in the order of ABCD before every journey.

However, one fateful day, as Simon arrived at the station to prepare his train, he noticed an unusual sight. The carriages were in complete disarray. They were in the order of DACB. Simon scratched his head in disbelief. This was a peculiar predicament.

Knowing that he had a crucial schedule to uphold, Simple Simon decided that he had no other choice but to gather the carriages onto the large rotating turntable. As they were uncoupled at a specific point, the train began to move. The remaining carriages, still attached, were subjected to a 180-degree rotation.

Sweat trickled down Simon's forehead as he tried to figure out how many rotations it would take to restore order to the carriages. With a determined look on his face, he embarked on his usual process. He focused on getting carriage A in the correct place, followed by carriage B, and so on.

One rotation... two rotations... three rotations... Simple Simon found himself crossing into unfamiliar territory. The carriages seemed unyielding, reluctant to fall into place. Four rotations... this was the maximum number of rotations that Simon had ever encountered to solve a problem like this before.

Finally, after the fifth rotation, the carriages were back to their original order of ABCD. Simon let out a sigh of relief, wiping the sweat from his brow. It had been a grueling journey, but he had prevailed.

As Simon continued his day, transporting villagers from one end of the village to the other, he couldn't help but wonder about the mathematical problem that had tested him. What if he had found a more efficient approach? What if there was a way to solve these maximix arrangements with fewer rotations?

Night fell, and Simple Simon couldn't shake the question from his mind. He sat in his train cabin, contemplating, staring into the darkness. With eleven carriages, countless possibilities waited to be explored. What would be the 2011th lexicographic maximix arrangement for eleven carriages? Was there a method that would require fewer rotations than the ones he had encountered before?

Simple Simon knew that there had to be a way, a more efficient approach that he was yet to discover. And so, with a renewed sense of purpose, he began his quest to unravel the mystery of the maximix arrangements.

But, dear reader, I ask you now, can you solve this mathematical problem that has been tormenting Simple Simon? Can you find the 2011th lexicographic maximix arrangement for eleven carriages?

title: Sum of a square and a cube
problem:
Many numbers can be expressed as the sum of a square and a cube. Some of them in more than one way.
Consider the palindromic numbers that can be expressed as the sum of a square and a cube, both greater than 1, in exactly 4 different ways.
For example, 5229225 is a palindromic number and it can be expressed in exactly 4 different ways:
22852 + 203
22232 + 663
18102 + 1253
11972 + 1563
Find the sum of the five smallest such palindromic numbers.
story:
Once upon a time in the mystical land of Numeria, there lived a young mathematician named Alex. Tall and bespectacled, Alex was known for his love for numbers and his insatiable curiosity. He spent most of his days delving into mathematical problems, seeking solace in the logic and structure they provided.

One sunny morning, as Alex was sipping his tea and pondering over a particularly perplexing problem, he stumbled upon a note tucked inside an ancient book of spells. The note contained a riddle that invoked his mathematical sensibilities.

"Many numbers can be expressed as the sum of a square and a cube. Some of them in more than one way. Consider the palindromic numbers that can be expressed as the sum of a square and a cube, both greater than 1, in exactly four different ways. Find the sum of the five smallest such palindromic numbers."

Intrigued by the challenge, Alex knew he had stumbled upon something extraordinary. The magical land of Numeria was renowned for its enigmatic powers, and he sensed a hidden web of secrets waiting to be unraveled. Determined to decipher the riddle, he set off on a quest to uncover the truth behind these palindromic numbers.

As Alex traveled through the enchanting forests and treacherous mountains of Numeria, he encountered different villagers who, too, were drawn to the mystery. Some admired his passion for numbers, while others scoffed at his relentless pursuit of solutions. Nevertheless, he pressed on, fueled by his unwavering determination to crack the riddle.

During his journey, Alex met a wise old sage named Elena, who had been studying Numeria's mysteries for decades. Elena recognized the riddle instantly and explained its deeper significance. Legend had it that these palindromic numbers held the key to unlocking the magical powers hidden within Numeria's ancient artifacts. If someone could solve this puzzle, they would be granted unimaginable abilities to shape the world.

With this newfound knowledge, Alex's quest took on a whole new purpose. He realized that the fate of Numeria rested on his ability to decipher the riddle and find the missing key that would unleash the magical powers. Guided by his instincts and emboldened by the responsibility thrust upon him, Alex dedicated himself to the task at hand.

Months turned into years as Alex tirelessly delved deeper into the mathematical problem, driven by an unquenchable curiosity. Along the way, he encountered characters from all walks of Numerian life – from humble farmers to elusive sorcerers – each with their own unique perspective on the riddle.

But it was Merlin, the renowned Numerian philosopher, who shed the most light on the significance of these palindromic numbers. According to Merlin, they were the threads that connected different realms of existence within Numeria. By unraveling these numbers, one could gain access to hidden realms, each more mysterious and powerful than the last.

As Alex stood in awe of the task before him, he realized the enormity of the challenge. The fate of Numeria's magic rested in his hands, and only by solving the riddle could he unlock the true potential of Numeria's artifacts. The five smallest palindromic numbers held the key, but the question remained: could Alex crack the code before it was too late?

And so, dear reader, this is where we leave Alex on his quest – standing at the cusp of greatness, with the power to shape the mystical land of Numeria within his mathematical grasp. But the question lingers, waiting to be answered: can you find the sum of the five smallest palindromic numbers that hold the key to Numeria's hidden magic?

title: Hexagonal orchards
problem:
A hexagonal orchard of order n is a triangular lattice made up of points within a regular hexagon with side n. The following is an example of a hexagonal orchard of order 5:




Highlighted in green are the points which are hidden from the center by a point closer to it. It can be seen that for a hexagonal orchard of order 5, 30 points are hidden from the center.


Let H(n) be the number of points hidden from the center in a hexagonal orchard of order n.


H(5) = 30. H(10) = 138. H(1 000) = 1177848.


Find H(100 000 000).
story:
Once upon a time in a forgotten corner of a bustling kingdom, there was a small village nestled amidst vast meadows and enchanting woodlands. The village, known as Hexington, was renowned for its mystical hexagonal orchard that lay at its heart. Legend had it that the orchard possessed a unique power that only the purest of hearts could unlock. And so, throughout the generations, the people of Hexington would venture into the orchard, seeking answers or solace in its inexplicable allure.

Among the villagers was a young girl named Eliza. With her wide, inquisitive eyes and a heart filled with wonder, Eliza dreamt of discovering the hidden mysteries that lay within the hexagonal orchard. She had heard tales of its magic and had seen the amazement in her older brother's eyes when he returned from his own journey through the orchard. Eliza longed to follow in his footsteps, but the villagers insisted she was too young to understand its secrets.

Determined, Eliza spent countless hours perched on the lumpy steps of the local library, devouring one book after another. She learned of the intricate patterns that made up the orchard, how its triangular lattice of points weaved together to create an enchanting hexagonal puzzle. The villagers marveled at Eliza's understanding of the orchard's composition, but still, they deemed her too young to venture inside.

One fateful day, as the village celebrated its annual Fall Festival, a mysterious stranger appeared in Hexington. The villagers whispered rumors of his extraordinary knowledge, whispering that he held the key not only to the orchard's magic but also to its protection. Intrigued and hopeful, Eliza approached the stranger, who had an air of wisdom and a mischievous gleam in his eyes.

"Young Eliza," the stranger said, his voice carrying a soothing melody. "Your thirst for knowledge radiates like the sun's rays. Come, for I have an adventure that awaits you."

Eliza's heart fluttered with anticipation as she followed the stranger into the depths of the hexagonal orchard. With every step, the air grew thicker, charged with an ancient energy that tickled her skin. The trees whispered secrets, and each cool breeze whispered forgotten tales.

"Eliza," the stranger spoke, his voice woven into the winds that caressed her ears. "The orchard hides its true essence, revealing only select points at a time. But do you know how many lie hidden within its embrace?"

Eliza furrowed her brows, pondering the stranger's question. She had delved deep into the hexagonal orchard's patterns, but she had never pondered the precise number of hidden points.

"The number of points hidden from the center," the stranger continued, his eyes twinkling with anticipation, "is a riddle in itself. For every twist and turn in the orchard's design holds a secret that few can fathom. I challenge you, Eliza, to unravel the truth."

As Eliza ventured onward, her mind whirred with calculations. Images of the hexagonal orchard flashed before her eyes as she raced to uncover the significance of the hidden points. The stranger watched her with pride, for he knew that he had found a worthy companion in his quest to safeguard the orchard's magic.

From that moment, Eliza became consumed by the allure of the hexagonal orchard. Day and night, she immersed herself in its secrets, scribbling equations and delving into the enigmatic patterns that danced beneath her fingertips. The villagers marveled at her newfound dedication, and soon they entrusted her with the task of protecting the orchard's magic, seeing her boundless potential.

Years passed, and Eliza's knowledge surpassed that of even the wisest sages in Hexington. She had charted the labyrinthine pathways of the hexagonal orchard, discovering the intricate relationships between its points and unraveling equations that told stories of hidden wonders. Yet, one mathematical problem remained unsolved—a mystery waiting for its final reckoning.

And so, dear reader, I shall pose to you the same question that weighed heavily on young Eliza's heart:

Can you find H(100,000,000)?

As Eliza stood at the precipice, her eyes tracing the final path through the hexagonal orchard, she marveled at the infinite possibilities that lay ahead. In your hands, the answer dwells, and the fate of the orchard's magic rests upon your resolve.

title: Cyclic numbers
problem:
A cyclic number with n digits has a very interesting property:
When it is multiplied by 1, 2, 3, 4, ... n, all the products have exactly the same digits, in the same order, but rotated in a circular fashion!


The smallest cyclic number is the 6-digit number 142857 :
142857 × 1 = 142857
142857 × 2 = 285714
142857 × 3 = 428571
142857 × 4 = 571428
142857 × 5 = 714285
142857 × 6 = 857142  


The next cyclic number is 0588235294117647 with 16 digits :
0588235294117647 × 1 = 0588235294117647
0588235294117647 × 2 = 1176470588235294
0588235294117647 × 3 = 1764705882352941
...
0588235294117647 × 16 = 9411764705882352


Note that for cyclic numbers, leading zeros are important.


There is only one cyclic number for which, the eleven leftmost digits are 00000000137 and the five rightmost digits are 56789 (i.e., it has the form 00000000137...56789 with an unknown number of digits in the middle). Find the sum of all its digits.
story:
Once upon a time, in a small village nestled at the foot of a towering mountain, there lived a young and curious girl named Lily. Lily was known for her insatiable appetite for knowledge and her penchant for unraveling mysteries. She spent her days exploring the lush forests surrounding the village, often finding hidden treasures and forgotten stories etched into the walls of ancient ruins.

One sunny afternoon, as Lily wandered deeper into the forest than ever before, she stumbled upon an old, weathered book. The pages were yellowed with age, and the cover seemed to whisper tales of forgotten wonders. Intrigued by the book's mysterious aura, Lily sat beneath a sturdy oak tree and began to read.

As she turned the pages, her eyes widened at the sight of a mathematical problem that seemed to leap off the page. It described a fascinating concept known as "cyclic numbers." The problem stated that a cyclic number with n digits possessed a remarkable property. When multiplied by 1, 2, 3, 4, and so on, up to n, all the products would have the same digits, but in a circular fashion. Lily's mind whirled with wonder and excitement.

Determined to unravel this mathematical marvel, Lily made it her mission to search for the smallest cyclic number. Armed with her newfound knowledge, she embarked on a journey across the land, seeking answers from wise scholars and sages. Month after month, she traveled far and wide, crossing treacherous mountain ranges and endless deserts.

One fateful evening, exhausted and disheartened, Lily stumbled upon an old hermit's cottage. Knocking on the door, she was greeted by a wizened old man named Ephraim. He listened attentively as Lily recounted her quest to find the smallest cyclic number.

Ephraim smiled knowingly, his eyes twinkling with wisdom. "Child, the smallest cyclic number is often found where we least expect it," he said. "It hides not only in the pages of ancient books but within the very fabric of our existence."

Intrigued, Lily asked Ephraim for more guidance. The old man reached into his cloak and pulled out a tattered parchment. "There is only one cyclic number with the eleven leftmost digits as 00000000137 and the five rightmost digits as 56789," he whispered. Now, dear reader, I pose the same question to you. Can you solve the conundrum of the unknown digits in the middle of this extraordinary cyclic number? Can you find the sum of all its digits? The story awaits its next chapter, and only you hold the key to unlock its secrets.

title: Hilbert's New Hotel
problem:
An infinite number of people (numbered 1, 2, 3, etc.) are lined up to get a room at Hilbert's newest infinite hotel. The hotel contains an infinite number of floors (numbered 1, 2, 3, etc.), and each floor contains an infinite number of rooms (numbered 1, 2, 3, etc.). 


Initially the hotel is empty. Hilbert declares a rule on how the nth person is assigned a room: person n gets the first vacant room in the lowest numbered floor satisfying either of the following:
the floor is empty
the floor is not empty, and if the latest person taking a room in that floor is person m, then m + n is a perfect square

Person 1 gets room 1 in floor 1 since floor 1 is empty.
Person 2 does not get room 2 in floor 1 since 1 + 2 = 3 is not a perfect square.
Person 2 instead gets room 1 in floor 2 since floor 2 is empty.
Person 3 gets room 2 in floor 1 since 1 + 3 = 4 is a perfect square.


Eventually, every person in the line gets a room in the hotel.


Define P(f, r) to be n if person n occupies room r in floor f, and 0 if no person occupies the room. Here are a few examples:
P(1, 1) = 1
P(1, 2) = 3
P(2, 1) = 2
P(10, 20) = 440
P(25, 75) = 4863
P(99, 100) = 19454


Find the sum of all P(f, r) for all positive f and r such that f × r = 71328803586048 and give the last 8 digits as your answer.
story:
Once upon a time, in a land known for its infinite wonders, there stood Hilbert's Infinite Hotel. People from far and wide flocked to this legendary establishment, eager to experience its infinite floors and endless possibilities. Among the curious travelers was a young mathematician named Amelia.

Finally, Amelia arrived at the designated floor and room number. She unlocked the door with anticipation, eager to uncover the numerical secrets hidden within. And there, written on the wall, was her assigned room number: P(f, r).

Amelia's mind whirred with numbers and calculations. She began to delve into the problem at hand, pondering different strategies to decipher the meaning behind P(f, r). The room felt like her personal laboratory, with the infinite possibilities of mathematics waiting at her fingertips.

Days turned into weeks during Amelia's stay at Hilbert's Infinite Hotel. She immersed herself in the depths of the mathematical puzzle, unraveling patterns and creating beautiful equations. Every time she encountered a new P(f, r), she would jot it down, adding to her growing list of discovered results.

As her departure date approached, Amelia found herself standing before Hilbert once again. She had discovered fascinating connections between the assigned room numbers and the nature of perfect squares. But she couldn't help but wonder if there was a way to solve the grand puzzle completely.

Mr. Hilbert smiled knowingly at Amelia. "Young mathematician, I can see the passion burning in your eyes. You have dived deeper than most into the wonders of this hotel. Amelia's heart raced with excitement. She knew she had come close to unlocking the secrets of this infinite puzzle, but the answer still eluded her grasp. Yet, she felt a sense of exhilaration, knowing that she had ventured into uncharted mathematical territory.

title: Sum of squares of divisors
problem:
The divisors of 6 are 1,2,3 and 6.
The sum of the squares of these numbers is 1+4+9+36=50.


Let sigma2(n) represent the sum of the squares of the divisors of n.
Thus sigma2(6)=50.

Let SIGMA2 represent the summatory function of sigma2, that is SIGMA2(n)=∑ sigma2(i) for i=1 to n.
The first 6 values of SIGMA2 are: 1,6,16,37,63 and 113.


Find SIGMA2(1015) modulo 109.
story:

title: Prime connection
problem:
Two positive numbers A and B are said to be connected (denoted by "A ↔ B") if one of these conditions holds:
(1) A and B have the same length and differ in exactly one digit; for example, 123 ↔ 173.
(2) Adding one digit to the left of A (or B) makes B (or A); for example, 23 ↔ 223 and 123 ↔ 23.


We call a prime P a 2's relative if there exists a chain of connected primes between 2 and P and no prime in the chain exceeds P.


For example, 127 is a 2's relative. One of the possible chains is shown below:
2 ↔ 3 ↔ 13 ↔ 113 ↔ 103 ↔ 107 ↔ 127
However, 11 and 103 are not 2's relatives.


Let F(N) be the sum of the primes ≤ N which are not 2's relatives.
We can verify that F(103) = 431 and F(104) = 78728.


Find F(107).
story:
Once upon a time in the quaint village of Numeria, there lived a young girl named Lily. title: Roots on the Rise
problem:
Let ak, bk, and ck represent the three solutions (real or complex numbers) to the equation
1x=(kx)2(k+x2)−kx.
For instance, for k=5, we see that {a5,b5,c5} is approximately {5.727244,−0.363622+2.057397i,−0.363622−2.057397i}.
Let S(n)=∑p=1n∑k=1n(ak+bk)p(bk+ck)p(ck+ak)p. 
Interestingly, S(n) is always an integer. For example, S(4)=51160.
Find S(106) modulo 1000000007.
story:

title: Sums of totients of powers
problem:
Let φ(n) be Euler's totient function.
Let f(n)=(∑i=1nφ(ni)) mod (n+1).
Let g(n)=∑i=1nf(i).
g(100)=2007.


Find g(5×108).

title: Chinese leftovers
problem:
Let g(a,n,b,m) be the smallest non-negative solution x to the system:x = a mod nx = b mod m
if such a solution exists, otherwise 0.


E.g. g(2,4,4,6)=10, but g(3,4,4,6)=0.


Let φ(n) be Euler's totient function.


Let f(n,m)=g(φ(n),n,φ(m),m)


Find ∑ f(n,m) for 1000000 ≤ n < m < 1005000
story:

title: Super Pandigital Numbers
problem:
A positive number is pandigital in base b if it contains all digits from 0 to b - 1 at least once when written in base b.
A n-super-pandigital number is a number that is simultaneously pandigital in all bases from 2 to n inclusively.
For example 978 = 11110100102 = 11000203 = 331024 = 124035 is the smallest 5-super-pandigital number.
Similarly, 1093265784 is the smallest 10-super-pandigital number.
The sum of the 10 smallest 10-super-pandigital numbers is 20319792309.
What is the sum of the 10 smallest 12-super-pandigital numbers?
story:

title: Pairwise Coin-Tossing Game
problem:
Consider an n-player game played in consecutive pairs: Round 1 takes place between players 1 and 2, round 2 takes place between players 2 and 3, and so on and so forth, all the way up to round n, which takes place between players n and 1. Then round n+1 takes place between players 1 and 2 as the entire cycle starts again.
In other words, during round r, player ((r−1)modn)+1 faces off against player (rmodn)+1.
During each round, a fair coin is tossed to decide which of the two players wins that round. If any given player wins both rounds r and r+1, then that player wins the entire game.
Let Pn(k) be the probability that player k wins in an n-player game, in the form of a reduced fraction. For example, P3(1)=12/49 and P6(2)=368/1323.
Let Mn(k) be the product of the reduced numerator and denominator of Pn(k). For example, M3(1)=588 and M6(2)=486864.
Find the last 8 digits of M108+7(104+7).
story:
Once upon a time, in the quiet village of Mathemoria, there lived a young girl named Lily. Lily had always been fascinated by numbers and had a knack for solving intriguing puzzles. She spent most of her time exploring the vast library in the village, seeking out new challenges to test her mathematical prowess.

One sunny afternoon, Lily stumbled upon an old, dusty book hidden away on a forgotten shelf. Its title read "The Enigmatic Coin Game." Intrigued, she opened the book and discovered a fascinating mathematical problem. The problem described a game played by n players in consecutive pairs. Excitedly, she delved into the intricacies of the game.

As she read, Lily became entranced by the complexity of the game. In each round, players faced off against each other, tossing a fair coin to determine the winner. To win the entire game, a player had to win both the current round and the following one. Lily couldn't help but imagine herself as one of the competitors, participating in this thrilling game of chance and strategy.

title: 2-Friendly
problem:
Two positive integers a and b are 2-friendly when gcd(a,b)=2t,t>0. For example, 24 and 40 are 2-friendly because gcd(24,40)=8=23 while 24 and 36 are not because gcd(24,36)=12=22⋅3 not a power of 2.
Let f(n) be the number of pairs, (p,q), of positive integers with 1≤p<q≤n such that p and q are 2-friendly. You are given f(102)=1031 and f(106)=321418433 modulo 1000000007.
Find f(1011) modulo 1000000007.
story:

title: Fibonacci paths
problem:
Alice walks on a lattice grid. She can step from one lattice point A(a,b) to another B(a+x,b+y) providing distance AB=x2+y2 is a Fibonacci number {1,2,3,5,8,13,…} and x≥0, y≥0.



In the lattice grid below Alice can step from the blue point to any of the red points.


Let F(W,H) be the number of paths Alice can take from (0,0) to (W,H).
You are given F(3,4)=278 and F(10,10)=215846462.


Find F(10000,10000)mod1000000007.

title: 2ω(n)
problem:
Let ω(n) denote the number of distinct prime divisors of a positive integer n.
So  ω(1)=0 and  ω(360)=ω(23×32×5)=3.


Let S(n) be Σd|n2ω(d).

E.g. S(6)=2ω(1)+2ω(2)+2ω(3)+2ω(6)=20+21+21+22=9.


Let F(n)=Σi=2nS(i!).
F(10)=4821.


Find F(10000000). Give your answer modulo  1000000087.
story:
Once upon a time in the charming town of Matheson, lived a young prodigy named Ethan. With his sharp intellect and love for all things mathematical, Ethan excelled in his studies and caught the attention of his teacher, Professor Adler.

One afternoon, when the sun bathed the quaint streets in a golden glow, Professor Adler invited Ethan to his home. The professor's house was filled with shelves of books and papers, bearing the weight of countless mathematical problems yet to be solved.

"Ethan, my boy," the professor said, a twinkle in his eyes, "I have a puzzle that's been puzzling me for quite some time. It involves a function called S(n) that calculates the sum of the divisors of a number, multiplied by the number's prime divisors. Fascinating, isn't it?"

Ethan quivered with excitement. "Yes, Professor Adler. Please tell me more."

The professor explained, "You see, S(n) is defined as the sum of 2 to the power of the number of prime divisors of n, multiplied by the sum of its divisors. And there's another function called F(n), which evaluates S(i!) for every integer i starting from 2 up to n, and sums them all up."

Ethan's eyes widened as he pondered the complexity of the problem. This was no ordinary arithmetic; it was a gateway to uncharted mathematical territories.

"Can you give me an example, Professor?"

"Of course, my boy," Professor Adler said with a smile. "Let's take S(6) as an example. It can be calculated by adding 2 to the power of the number of prime divisors of each divisor of 6 squared. So, S(6) will be equal to 2ω(1) + 2ω(2) + 2ω(3) + 2ω(6). In this case, ω(1) = 0, ω(2) = 1, ω(3) = 1, and ω(6) = 2. Hence, S(6) equals 20 + 21 + 21 + 22, which is 9."

Ethan's eyes sparkled with eagerness. Professor Adler noticed his budding curiosity and continued, "Now, Ethan, here's where your puzzle-solving skills come into play. I need you to calculate F(10). It's the sum of S(i!) for i ranging from 2 to 10. Can you do it?"

Ethan's mind raced. He quickly scribbled down the values of S(i!) for each value of i and skillfully calculated F(10) to be 4821. But the math prodigy knew this was only the beginning. The professor had teased his mind with a taste of the mathematical enigma at hand.

As Ethan left Professor Adler's house, he couldn't help but feel the weight of the puzzle on his shoulders. The question lingered in his mind, beckoning him to solve it completely. What lay beyond F(10)? What would F(10000000) reveal? And why was the answer to be given modulo 1000000087?

Determined to unlock the truth, Ethan dove into a world of prime numbers, divisors, and sums. Days turned into weeks, weeks into months, and months into years. The town of Matheson witnessed the blossoming of his talent as he conquered countless mathematical conundrums and emerged a wiser, stronger mathematician.

And now, dear reader, it falls upon you to complete this tale. Can you find the elusive F(10000000)? What secrets will it unveil about the mysterious function S(n)? And why must the answer be given modulo 1000000087?

The answer awaits, as the town of Matheson holds its breath for the next brilliant mind to unravel this mathematical marvel. Will it be you?

title: Total Inversion Count of Divided Sequences
problem:
The inversion count of a sequence of digits is the smallest number of adjacent pairs that must be swapped to sort the sequence.
For example, 34214 has inversion count of 5:
34214→32414→23414→23144→21344→12344.


If each digit of a sequence is replaced by one of its divisors a divided sequence is obtained. 
For example, the sequence 332 has 8 divided sequences: {332,331,312,311,132,131,112,111}.


Define G(N) to be the concatenation of all primes less than N, ignoring any zero digit. 
For example, G(20)=235711131719.


Define F(N) to be the sum of the inversion count for all possible divided sequences from the master sequence G(N). 
You are given F(20)=3312 and F(50)=338079744.


Find F(108). Give your answer modulo 1000000007.

title: Exponent Difference
problem:
For any integer n>0 and prime number p, define νp(n) as the greatest integer r such that pr divides n. 


Define D(n,m)=∑p prime|νp(n)−νp(m)|. For example, D(14,24)=4.


Furthermore, define S(N)=∑1≤n,m≤ND(n,m). You are given S(10)=210 and S(102)=37018.


Find S(1012). Give your answer modulo 1000000007.

title: Duodigits
problem:
We call a natural number a duodigit if its decimal representation uses no more than two different digits.
For example, 12, 110 and 33333 are duodigits, while 102 is not.
It can be shown that every natural number has duodigit multiples. Let d(n) be the smallest (positive) multiple of the number n that happens to be a duodigit. For example, d(12)=12, d(102)=1122, d(103)=515, d(290)=11011010 and d(317)=211122.

Let D(k)=∑n=1kd(n). You are given D(110)=11047, D(150)=53312 and D(500)=29570988.

Find D(50000). Give your answer in scientific notation rounded to 13 significant digits (12 after the decimal point). If, for example, we had asked for D(500) instead, the answer format would have been 2.957098800000e7.

title: Summation of a Modular Formula
problem:
For an odd prime p, define f(p)=⌊2(2p)p⌋mod2p
For example, when p=3, ⌊28/3⌋=85≡5(mod8) and so f(3)=5.
Further define g(p)=f(p)modp. You are given g(31)=17.
Now define G(N) to be the summation of g(p) for all odd primes less than N.
You are given G(100)=474 and G(104)=2819236.
Find G(107)

title: Slowly converging series
problem:
For a non-negative integer k, define
Ek(q)=∑n=1∞σk(n)qn
where σk(n)=∑d∣ndk is the sum of the k-th powers of the positive divisors of n.
It can be shown that, for every k, the series Ek(q) converges for any 0<q<1.
For example,
E1(1−124)=3.872155809243e2
E3(1−128)=2.767385314772e10
E7(1−1215)=6.725803486744e39
All the above values are given in scientific notation rounded to twelve digits after the decimal point.
Find the value of E15(1−1225).
Give the answer in scientific notation rounded to twelve digits after the decimal point.

title: Triangle of Circular Arcs
problem:
Let ra, rb and rc be the radii of three circles that are mutually and externally tangent to each other. The three circles then form a triangle of circular arcs between their tangency points as shown for the three blue circles in the picture below.




Define the circumcircle of this triangle to be the red circle, with centre D, passing through their tangency points. Further define the incircle of this triangle to be the green circle, with centre E, that is mutually and externally tangent to all the three blue circles. Let d=|DE| be the distance between the centres of the circumcircle and the incircle.

Let E(d) be the expected value of d when ra, rb and rc are integers chosen uniformly such that 1≤ra<rb<rc≤100 and gcd(ra,rb,rc)=1.

Find E(d), rounded to eight places after the decimal point.
story:

Days turned into weeks, and the trio became ever more determined to unlock the secrets of the inscription. They encountered numerous challenges and setbacks along their journey but pressed on with unfaltering determination.

During their travels, the siblings met an eccentric mathematician named Professor Devlin. He had spent his life studying circles and their properties. The siblings listened intently as Professor Devlin explained that the distance 'd' was closely related to the proportions and spatial arrangements of the circles. The professor guided them through a mathematical maze, teaching them about the relationships between the radii and how they contributed to the formation of the triangle of circular arcs.

As Alice, Ben, and Charlie absorbed this newfound knowledge, they realized that the mathematical problem posed by the inscription had practical implications. The siblings embarked on a series of experiments to investigate the properties of the circles. With each trial, they refined their measurements and calculations, inching closer to the answer. They marveled at how their seemingly playful quest was unfolding into a real-life mathematical puzzle.

Their journey had not only brought them closer to solving the problem but also deepened their bond as siblings. Together, they overcame challenges, celebrated small victories, and continued to nurture their insatiable curiosity. title: Ascending subsequences
problem:
Let ai be the sequence defined by ai=153imod10000019 for i≥1.
The first terms of ai are:
153,23409,3581577,7980255,976697,9434375,…


Consider the subsequences consisting of 4 terms in ascending order. For the part of the sequence shown above, these are:
153,23409,3581577,7980255
153,23409,3581577,9434375
153,23409,7980255,9434375
153,23409,976697,9434375
153,3581577,7980255,9434375 and
23409,3581577,7980255,9434375.


Define S(n) to be the sum of the terms for all such subsequences within the first n terms of ai. Thus S(6)=94513710.
You are given that S(100)=4465488724217.


Find S(106) modulo 1000000007.
story:

title: Summation of Summations
problem:
Take a sequence of length n. Discard the first term then make a sequence of the partial summations. Continue to do this over and over until we are left with a single term. We define this to be f(n).


Consider the example where we start with a sequence of length 8:


11111111123456725914202751428487514429016542132297132429429


Then the final number is 429, so f(8)=429.


For this problem we start with the sequence 1,3,4,7,11,18,29,47,…
This is the Lucas sequence where two terms are added to get the next term. 
Applying the same process as above we get f(8)=2663.
You are also given f(20)=742296999 modulo 1000000007


Find f(108). Give your answer modulo 1000000007.
story:

title: Powers of 1+7
problem:
When (1+7) is raised to an integral power, n, we always get a number of the form (a+b7).
We write (1+7)n=α(n)+β(n)7.


For a given number x we  define g(x) to be the smallest positive integer n such that:
α(n)≡1(modx)and β(n)≡0(modx)
and g(x)=0 if there is no such value of n. For example, g(3)=0, g(5)=12.


Further define
G(N)=∑x=2Ng(x)
You are given G(102)=28891 and G(103)=13131583.


Find G(106).
story:
Once upon a time, in the intriguing land of Mathlandia, there lived a young prodigy named Ella. α(n)≡1(modx) and β(n)≡0(modx)
and g(x)=0 if there is no such value of n. For example, g(3)=0, g(5)=12.

Further define G(N)=∑x=2Ng(x)
You are given G(102)=28891 and G(103)=13131583.

title: A squared recurrence relation
problem:
The function f is defined for all positive integers as follows:
f(1)=1f(2n)=2f(n)f(2n+1)=2n+1+2f(n)+1nf(n)
It can be proven that f(n) is integer for all values of n.
The function S(n) is defined as S(n)=∑i=1nf(i)2.
For example, S(10)=1530 and S(102)=4798445.
Find S(1016). Give your answer modulo 1000000007.
story:
Once upon a time in the magical land of Numeria, there lived a young wizard named Ethan. Ethan was not like other wizards, for his mind was always bursting with numbers and equations. He spent most of his days in his small study, immersed in his books, solving mathematical puzzles and unraveling complex problems.

One day, as Ethan was deep in thought, his mentor and the elder wizard, Merlin, stepped into his study.

"What is it, Merlin? How can I help?" Ethan asked, eager to prove himself.

Merlin placed an ancient scroll on the table in front of Ethan. "This is a remarkable mathematical problem that has been plaguing Numeria for centuries. It involves a mysterious function called 'f'."

Ethan's eyes lit up with curiosity. "Tell me more, Merlin. I want to understand."

Merlin cleared his throat before explaining, "The function f is defined for all positive integers. It is a recursive function that has three cases. When f(1) = 1, f(2n) = 2f(n), and f(2n+1) = 2n + 1 + 2f(n) + 1 × f(n). This function somehow ensures that f(n) is an integer for all values of 'n'."

As Ethan absorbed the information, his mind began to generate thoughts and possibilities. "So if I understand correctly, Merlin, the function 'f' operates in a unique and complex way, but it always results in an integer?"

Merlin nodded with a smile, impressed by Ethan's comprehension. "Precisely, my boy. And that brings us to the function 'S'. The function 'S' is defined as the sum of f(i) squared, from i equals 1 to 'n'. It's a fascinating formula that has caught the attention of mathematicians from all over Numeria."

Ethan's eyes gleamed with excitement. "And you want me to find S(1016)?"

Merlin nodded. "Indeed, Ethan. Numeria is in dire need of your skills. The solutions you come up with could have infinite possibilities. They may enlighten us and bring about great advancements."

Ethan felt a surge of responsibility and determination. He knew he had a monumental task ahead of him, one that would require all his intellect and creativity. But he also knew that this was his purpose, his calling.

As Merlin left Ethan in his study, he closed the door behind him, leaving the young wizard to delve into the depths of the problem. Days turned into weeks, and weeks turned into months. Each night, he would put his quill aside, rest his weary eyes, and ponder the possibilities. In his mind, he began to see patterns emerging, connections forming, and solutions ready to be unearthed.

The people of Numeria waited with bated breath, as rumors began to spread of Ethan's progress. The weight of expectation settled upon his young shoulders, but he pressed on with determination, fueled by his love for numbers.
